Hextech Protobelt's an experiment on our part to see whether we can offer a trade off of raw combat power (stats on other items) versus windowed mobility (the active on the belt, which contrasts with the always on movement speed other AP mobility items offer). What we're hoping to find is a sweet spot where the belt's of use to some champions regularly and other champs occasionally, but requires you give up noticeable combat power for the dash. It should feel like something you pay a price for if you're willing, not something many champs just get for free. 

We'll be adding in some form of brief cast disable while using until just after using the belt (cast delay or self silence) in order to avoid it only being used as part of an instant burst combo (concern being that that case otherwise dominates any other possible use). Despite that, and the stats trade off, it's also possible we still won't see the desired sort of play with the belt, with it either only being used it unhealthy cases or being mandatory on too many AP despite the costs. Our current thinking is that we'll just remove the item sometime a few patches post launch if that's the case. We're looking to make our items more distinct and less 'stat stick' though, hence the desire to try deliberate experiments like this that do have some significant known risk to them.

Use it as an experiment then, but don't release to live servers if you know its going to fail. I don't want to have to wait 2-3 patches for this disgusting item to be out and being abused by the champions that we know will abuse the item.

If we knew it was going to fail we wouldn't put it on the PBE, let alone the live servers. There's certainly a risk it's a problem we have to remove, we believe there's a good chance it works out or at the very least teaches us something useful though. There are definitely a lot of possible problem cases that can be described on paper, as with Duskblade though we believe that a lot of things that initially appear problematic can potentially be addressed in game though.

Possible tuning levers include upping the cost, changing the build path or adjusting the stats to make if effectively not viable as a first major item as well. Can you explain to me why does this item need a double functionality as both a dash and a funky AoE damage ability?

It takes away from the items identity and just makes teamfights more confusing. It would be like giving AoE to QSS, Zhonya or any other actives...

Sure, few reasons:

1. So that if you're using it purely for the mobility (e.g. dashing back whenever threatened in lane) you're giving up some of the item's power to do so. We're looking at ways to reward aggressive, or at least interactive, play.

2. To add some additional depth to the belt's usage. Dash in a direction's fairly easy to optimize. Dash in a direction with directional damage that can be focused on one target, split across multiple or sacrificed entirely on the other hand has a lot more nuance to it.

3. As a way of binding it to its intended users. Putting some of the item's power budget into damage that scales with AP (from other sources primarily, given there's not that much on the belt) will hopefully allow a clear, solid bind towards champs that build a lot of AP, not equal value for anyone that wants the mobility and is ok with the stats.

3: Let me compare the item with Luden's Echo.

negative:
- 20 AP
- 10% MS
- active has a 30 second cd, Luden's does not (~5-10 seconds charging, depending on champ)
positive:
- 300 Cost
+ 300 HP
+ 10% cdr
+ active has 100-250% the damage of Luden's passive (basedamage, scaling stays at 250%) + more targets or multihit with reduced dmg
+ the 300 range dash that is completed in 1/4 of a second; 71% of flash range

Luden's Echo is already a decent item to rush, if one wants to push it for early kills. Now for comparing those stats.

 * 20AP: definitely something big when looking for an early kill
 * 10%MS: good for roaming and helps sidestepping, doesn't really contribute to raw combat though. It's basically just an increased chance to dodge a skillshot, which already exists
 * cooldown: Only a few champions can trigger Luden's twice per 1v1 skirmish, so the cooldown is pretty much negligable. Thus, I will now compare one use of Luden's to one use of HRB
 * 300 gold: Definitely noticable. That's either enough money for boots (to compensate 10% ms), or to get cloth armor (another combat stat; zed still exists, and other champs use basic attcks too)
 * 300 HP: Makes an enormous difference in combat
 * 10% cdr: not exactly noteworthy for burst-poke, but a slightly extended fight can already make it worth. Like how champions might fight that would consider this item. Fizz comes to mind, without spending too much thought.
 * +15% ap scaling (assuming the player only hits 1 of the 9? projectiles)

Now comparing the combat that involves activating HRB once, and Luden's once. A typical AP caster combo converts about 300% AP (I'm being generous here)

Luden's; player has a minimum of 100AP:

 * combo damage : 300 (only counting ap _scaling_; duh)
 * item damage: 100+30

HRB; player has a minimum of 80AP:

 * combo damage : 240 (only counting ap _scaling_; duh)
 * item damage: ~~100~~ 145+75
That's on level one. The base damage on a realistic level - say, 6 - would be + ~45

So the direct comparison at this point is 300+ (100+30) = **430** against 240+ (145+75) = **460**. And with every tiny extra piece of Ap, this difference grows. We didn't account for the extra hits for 15% yet

Assuming that the both opposing players built, Luden's on one side, and HRB+Boots on the other, the player with HRB now has an advantage in CDR, HP and damage, while taking a minor hit in MS. Obviously this scenario is highly convoluted. A slightly more realistic scenario would be, that both players first rush a manafixer, that for the sake of comparability will be the exact same item on both sides. But that also means that the HRB user profits more, due to additional AP that is converted by the AP scaling. I'm well aware that it's technically a skillshot, but please think about this: **Who likes a combination of AP, tank-stats and mobility?**. I'm thinking about: Fizz, Diana, Udyr, Ekko, Akali, Katarina. Basically everyone loves mobility, but there are a few noteworthy examples, like Ekko, Udyr and Fizz. Those that already manage to come up close to land an easy hit, but now get an extra tool to close gaps, become an annoyance to hit with skillshots and even get some more tankiness to survive that easier. meanwhile casters don't even look at the 300 range. The immobile ones can use it to some extent, I admit. But what about the active? Imo this part sucks balls for ranged casters. The projectiles can miss on long ranges, and using the mobility part defensively (when some annoying melee is already in your face), negates the damage entirely, because the blast doesn't fire in the opposite direction.

TLDR:
You're introducing a pretty good item here, that rather profits Assassins than casters, and I don't like it. I think the mechanic is interesting, but will either be broken good and then needs to be nerfed until everybody goes back to buying Luden's. And that's not the point when introducing a new item for more diversity. And please: before you nerf champions that somehow abuse that item to the fullest, consider removing it. Rito's history of jungle items and champion nerfs connected to it gave me serious ~~ca~~... headaches.

While you're commenting on the subject, any chance of trying an item that rewards not moving (or moving less). Maybe something that puts a zone on the ground (with a short channel to discourage use for or in response to assassination) which gives x% ap but which disappears if you move away from it or something else similar in this design space?

Please tell me this item isn't going to be shit, and if not, I certainly hope its not a must buy on everyone. You may as well of given everyone flash for free at that point, I just cannot see this item being good unless its overpowered statwise.

It's funny because during Season 3, assassins were extremely powerful, but YOU COULD OUTPLAY THEM. There was a clear, concise "If Talon jumps on me, I use Gravity Field ON MYSELF as Viktor" and that opened up either a "Nuke him to death" or poke him to half his HP. This was back when Talon had a Silence too, Viktor had to choose one Hexcore out of 3, and Viktor in general was known for requiring high mechanical skill. I COULD OUTPLAY SOMEONE and IT FELT GOOD when I did. I started playing against high ELO players regularly in Normals as a result (which prompted me to ignore Ranked). 

Now I feel like it's a lot harder to do that because the game's pacing, snowballing, and scaling has drastically improved for assassins. Viktor has also seen nerf after nerf, which speaks volumes when I struggle to maintain proper CS as a mage, but the assassin laner can keep doing the same old shit they've always been doing. I'm not saying mages in general are doing poorly because that would ignore Lux/Brand/Malzahar/Viktor/Vel'Koz/Anivia that are/were extremely potent in their own rights this season (until nerfs, but w/e). I AM saying that Riot has given other classes quite the boost in power and capacity SOONER than mages - it's as if mages have been forced into being weak early, strong midgame, then completely limbo at the endgame when anyone can kill you with base damage alone.

How does an armor item that simply makes you take less damage qualify as outplay and skill, but a mobility tool that allows you to dodge a skillshot or reposition to an advantageous area does not? Is searching in the shop and hitting the 'buy' button really difficult for you?

An item that makes you take less damage, gives you the opportunity to play around the high burst high mobility kit of an assassin and punish them with a well aimed skillshot or spell combo.
It is sad that you need defensive items as a damage dealer, but the meta assassin/tank is like that.

Logically though the champion which requires more skill and better positioning, reading, and tacticianing should have a bit of an edge over their facerolling counterpart.

That aside, there needs to be better itemisation to help level the playing field and really make things even.

Assassins counter carries, so it makes sense that it should be WAY easier for an Assassin to beat a Mage than the other way around.

However in a team fight situation, Mages have far higher value than Assassins assuming your team has half a brain, to the point where most people would consider it a very worth it to trade an Assassin for a mage in a fight.
